text: A place for the Golden Magus' many acolytes to study and display their sorcerous abilities.
In this part of the ship, the more experienced Magicians can hone their magic skills.
Only the Magus' most trusted magical pupils are allowed to enter this part of the ship.
Being both a pleasure barge and a corsair ship, the Flaming Scimitar is only lightly armed with smaller bronze cannons, instead of the heavier artillery of other pirate ships.
From this lookout, the Magus' magician servants cast the most potent spells to aid his forces in battle.
The Minaret of Tempests is where the Golden Magus and his most powerful acolytes cast their strongest spells, directed at enemy forces.

Inside this awe-inspiring golden tower is where the source of the Golden Magus' powers resides. Hidden within, in a location known only to the Magus himself, reside three magical urns containing the fabled Royal Djinns, drained of their energies for the Magus' benefit.

...The Magus stood up, stretching like a cat in the morning sun. He would allow\\nhimself a break from the frenetically entertaining world of men for a while, perhaps,\\nand spend a little time as a king instead of a servant....
There are many small towns such as this dotting the large swathes of the Arabyan deserts, with its folk often minding their own business detracted from common worldly affairs.
In Araby, small coastal towns such as this heavily rely on pearl trading aside from the usual fishing that goes on over here.

Makeshift markets are a fairly common sight in Arabyan settlements. One might feel at home between hagglers trying to sway potential customers over here and the occasional thief pickpocketing a confused bystander over there.
Bustling ports and sea-side bazaars span the length of the coast in this town. Slowly but surely, the town is bound to grow to accommodate more traders from lands far and wide!
Welcome friend! You will find all sorts of goods and products here! L-look, silk! Silk from faraway Cathay! Aa-and over here, this is a special product - a genie lamp! You will...

Ships from all four corners of the world sail back and forth from these Arabyan coastal cities. Jewels of the desert abundant in resources gained by bartering with traders from the lands of faraway Cathay, mysterious realms of Nippon, jungles of Lustria, the human principalities of the Empire, and even some Norscan tribes.

The larger Arabyan cities mark the epitome of how advanced Arabyan engineering has become. Graceful artisanship of marble-carving has produced stunning results. Dome and column, adorned with glamorous hints of gold. This is a testament of Arabyan – and, indeed, human – might!
Prospering betwixt marble columns and golden domes proud, these Arabyan cities are a work of human ingenuity! Unbeknownst to many though, you may find the usual Skaven under-city from time to time...

Mighty domed palaces laced together to form structures that no living - nor dead - has ever witnessed before. These are confined within tremendously tall walls, in itself surrounded by the greater city. The Sultans call this place home, and woe to any who might trespass against their will!

The Arabyans are a proud people... As such, they have built their greatest cities through sweat and blood! Unmatched in architecture and engineering, this city hosts the most grandiose bazaars and ports to be found in Araby. You might also witness the High Elven embassies and trading posts, something you would rarely find outside Ulthuan.

Small camps that are called home by newly civilized Desert Tribes. They still have a long way to get accustomed to city culture, but as long as they take care of the livestock most Sultans don't really bat an eye.
In Araby, small coastal towns such as this heavily rely on pearl trading aside from the usual fishing that goes on over here.
Villages such as these deal most of their commerce in farming and hunting. You will, however, find the occasional caravan stop somewhere that allows such villages to one day become bustling cities.
Bustling ports and sea-side bazaars span the length of the coast in this town. Slowly but surely, the town is bound to grow to accommodate more traders from lands far and wide!

Whether they're on the Silk Road or not, Arabyans will always find a way to trade and make coin. And soon enough, their cities will slowly fill the old world - and perhaps the new - in marble and stone, if left unopposed!

Ships from all four corners of the world sail back and forth from these Arabyan coastal cities. Jewels of the desert abundant in resources gained by bartering with traders from the lands of faraway Cathay, mysterious realms of Nippon, jungles of Lustria, the human principalities of the Empire, and even some Norscan tribes.

The Aswad Scythans are loyal servants of the Tomb Kings and go to great lengths to protect and maintain their masters' crypts, in turn, the masters will not hesitate to defend their faithful subjects.
Known as the City of Thieves, it is the largest commercial port in Araby. Home of the Great Sultan, hub of commerce and capital of Araby.
Under a swift sunrise, the Dhows set out from the docks on their daily routine of carrying Arabyan sailors amidst the seas and oceans for various purposes, most notably pearl hunting.
Corsairs and Merchants from all walks of life can be found here, all focused on one task - to make the most coin possible, doesn't matter how it's done.
In the largest Arabyan cities, you may find harbours entirely dedicated to shipping and receiving slaves. After all, it is on the backs of slaves that the greatest empires are built!

A city without its guard is a city left to the pickings of thieves and marauders. Thus, it is the city guard's duty to prevent just that from happening! With the usual execution displays in the public square, to ensure a safe and secure... society.
Luxurious barracks usually exist to employ the proud Arabyan Knights - dedicated to their faith and Sultan!

The Arabyan Guard - those dedicated to guarding the Sultans and Caliphs - are stationed in designated barracks that lie within the royal palaces for absolute protection. None would dare step within these premises.
The Sultan's best cavalrymen also have the finest equipment available in their barracks.
The deserts are littered with the camps of nomadic warriors.
A place for the Nomadic tribes to put aside their petty squabbles and unify as one in such dire times.
From the Southlands come hardy warriors to sell their services to the highest bidder.
Camels are irreplaceable for the nomadic tribes of the desert and are thus well cared for.
Stabling yards are where the young warriors train with their steeds, learning to shoot from the saddle.
Liveries are more than mere stables – they are where the proudest mounts of the Tribes are kept.
A place to hold the dangerous and exotic beasts that the Waghzen use as mounts.
A simple shrine, to pray homage to the many elemental spirits.
Temples of the Djinn, to which the faithful come to pray and make offerings.
The largest buildings of the Djinn cult are the domed and richly decorated Masjids dedicated to the worship of the elemental spirits.
Huge stables built to keep the imposing and exotic animals of the Southlands.
The nobles of Araby collect every imaginable kind of exotic animal and keep them in their vast menageries.
Here, skilled carpenters build the sophisticated artillery pieces used in the Arabyan armies.
One who is well-versed in the secrets of shaping ores into gun and artillery barrels. It is a skill set in much demand.
When the finest blacksmithing skills and alchemical secrets are combined, truly fearsome weapons are created.
The first line of defense of Arabyan cities is manned by expendable slave fighters.
Cities are usually ringed by high walls of sandstone to defend against threats within and without the realm’s borders.
The largest of settlements will have great walls, many feet thick, and reinforced with pillars of stone.
These small posts dot the Arabyan frontier often serving as a base for further conquests with many developing into urban and administrative centres.
A larger fortification used to garrison Arabyan forces but also encompass markets and meeting points for the tribes living beyond the border.
Goat keeping has a long tradition in Araby, as few livestock can find fodder on the barren soils.
The so-called bread of the desert grows in the many oases and has also been cultivated for thousands of years.
When water is scarce, it must be brought from where it is abundant.
Artfully hand-knotted carpets can be found in every Arabyan household. Some serve as more than just decoration.
Skilled craftsmen create the breathtaking mosaic artworks that adorn the magnificent desert cities.
Rose water is used to create beguiling fragrances that are especially popular among the nobility.
Patrons talk as they sit around smoking from large ornamental hookahs.
Larger establishments offer mouth-watering delicacies, exotic drinks and serve as social gathering places.
An even larger establishment that offers other mouth-watering delicacies...
One hundred Dinars? Two hundred? Do we have a deal? Remember folks, this one is well-built and young in its years! Oh-what's that? SOLD!
In the Arena, a man is made and unmade a hundred times, until death.
A tent where physicians and pharmacists practice until they move on to the next town.
A house of curing for the sick and a place of learning for medical students.
With their shadows flickering from the incandescent light of enchanted torches, the night watchmen make their rounds.
A trained force of Watchmen scour the tunnels beneath the city, staying alert to any sign of the filthy creatures that might call these hollows home.
Hunters, trackers and warriors of the highest calibre all do their part to patrol the underground in search of foul ratkin.
Small gardens where the aromatic coffee beans are grown.
Larger plantations serve to meet the high demand for the invigorating drink.
The delicious aroma of freshly roasted coffee beans drifts through the streets near the roastery.

Inside a forgotten rocky valley near the World's Edge Mountains lies the tomb of Karitamen, the Death Scarab himself, and deadly foe to Princess Fatandira and her people. The Liche Lord is conspicuously absent, but has left behind many riches and servants, ripe for the taking...

The largest of them all is the Palace of the Great Sultan. It is famous for its riches and luxuries, with large libraries brimming with ancient and unique books, and with temples decorated with idols of the Djinn, the gods of Araby.

The glory of the past rises here, in what was the most beautiful wonder in the world, the Gardens of Bel-Aliad. Its vision is a reflection of what Araby once was, the greatest human civilization in the world.
This grandiose tomb is the greatest pride of the Arabyans. The first Great Sultan, Mullah Aklan’d, lies here. His legend still lives in the hearts of the inhabitants of this land.

Tactile and elegant, Ivory is held in the highest regard to the denizens of Ka-Sabar. This palace was built in tribute to Kasoun by the master architects of Ka-Sabar, and has become the formal residence of the ruling Sultans ever since.

It is spoken throughout Araby that there is little about the art of sorcery that the Wizard Caliph does not know, and he specialises in the lifting and laying of curses. Of course for any service the Caliph is sure to ask a favour in return.
The one who was the ruler of the southern seas built this mighty fortress. Nafel Muq ruled the oceans like a tyrant, and the Arabyan corsairs continue his path.

This Tower serves as a testament of Arabyan might; to those who dared pillage and burn their lands and cities for centuries. As a symbol of benevolence; from those who vowed not to do to their aggressors what was done unto them. And a mark of terror; to any who might dare threaten Araby ever again!
The memory of the night continues to haunt the Arabyans, however, there are some who crave such power. Inside these chambers sleeps the dark shadow that once devastated this land.
A nameless horror lives behind its border. A land that knows no other will than that of its tyrannical gods. Many have passed through it, but no one has been able to return...
The sentient whirlpool at the centre of the Galleon's Graveyard pulls great sea-going vessels into its gaping maw, wherein Noctilus bides his time and awaits his chance.
The docks of Copher are famed for its spice trade, which earned the city the name City of Spices. But it is also feared for its pirates...
The Arabyan College of Sorcerers teaches gifted students from across the peninsula in the ways of Magic.
The legend of this terrible city has reached every corner of the globe, as it is said to be the place where all slaves taken in the mortal world eventually end up to be sold.
The peaks of the Atalan Mountains are inhabited by many beasts, including the Giant Vultures and Radiant Pegasi.
The sand-buried graves of the Tomb Kings are filled with immeasurable treasures. One only has to dare dig them up.
At last, the Maelstrom belongs to the Golden Magus and with his magic he can become the most powerful Djinn summoner in the world.
Now the masquerade falls and the Golden Magus shows where his true loyalties lie. The power of the Maelstrom belongs to the God of Change and he rewards his servants richly.
